articles.headline: Justices Reject Inmate Right to DNA Tests
articles.snippet: Convicts do not have a right under the Constitution to obtain DNA testing to try to prove their innocence long after being found guilty, the Supreme Court ruled.
articles.abstract: Convicts do not have a right under the Constitution to obtain DNA testing to try to prove their innocence long after being found guilty, the Supreme Court ruled.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  Prisoners have no constitutional right to DNA testing that might prove their innocence, the Supreme Court ruled on Thursday in a 5-to-4 decision.

articles.headline: Senators Skeptical of Financial Regulation Plan
articles.snippet: The Treasury secretary said the Federal Reserve’s powers would not expand greatly under a planned reform of financial regulation.
articles.abstract: The Treasury secretary said the Federal Reserve’s powers would not expand greatly under a planned reform of financial regulation.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  President Obama’s plan to overhaul the regulatory structure of the nation’s financial system faces formidable obstacles on Capitol Hill, if the reception accorded Timothy F. Geithner, the Treasury secretary, on Thursday was any indication.

articles.headline: Obama’s Pledge on Donations Faces Reality
articles.snippet: The president’s promise to change Washington is colliding with the realities of money, influence and governance.
articles.abstract: The president’s promise to change Washington is colliding with the realities of money, influence and governance.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  When President Obama arrived at the Mandarin Oriental hotel for a fund-raising reception on Thursday night, the new White House rules of political purity were in order: no lobbyists allowed.

articles.headline: Couple’s Capital Ties Said to Veil Spying for Cuba
articles.snippet: Prosecutors say that a disdain for U.S. foreign policy drove a Washington couple to spy for Cuba for nearly 30 years.
articles.abstract: Prosecutors say that a disdain for U.S. foreign policy drove a Washington couple to spy for Cuba for nearly 30 years.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  She was twice divorced and fresh out of South Dakota when she fell for his worldly sophistication. He came from one of this city’s most privileged families, and admired her work helping ordinary people.

articles.headline: Democrats Scramble to Cut Costs From Health Plan
articles.snippet: The high cost of broadening access to health insurance has Democrats scrambling to scale back their proposals.
articles.abstract: The high cost of broadening access to health insurance has Democrats scrambling to scale back their proposals.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  The high cost of securing health insurance for all Americans, the top domestic priority of President Obama, has Congressional Democrats scrambling to scale back their proposals or find ways to trim tens of billions of dollars a year from existing health programs.

articles.headline: Reader’s Digest Searches for a Contemporary Niche
articles.snippet: The magazine has dropped generic how-to magazine features for inspiring spiritual articles and tales of military life.
articles.abstract: The magazine has dropped generic how-to magazine features for inspiring spiritual articles and tales of military life.
articles.lead_paragraph: For 87 years, Reader’s Digest, that monthly breadbasket of condensed articles, can-do tales and grandmother-approved jokes, has aimed squarely at Middle America.

articles.headline: A Move to Put the Union Label on Solar Power Plants
articles.snippet: If companies commit at the outset to use union labor, they say environmental objections never materialize.
articles.abstract: If companies commit at the outset to use union labor, they say environmental objections never materialize.
articles.lead_paragraph: SACRAMENTO  When a company called Ausra filed plans for a big solar power plant in California, it was deluged with demands from a union group that it study the effect on creatures like the short-nosed kangaroo rat and the ferruginous hawk.

articles.headline: A Credit Squeeze for Small-Business Owners
articles.snippet: A crackdown on credit limits by card companies is squeezing the nation’s small businesses, exacerbating the problems caused by a stagnant economy.
articles.abstract: A crackdown on credit limits by card companies is squeezing the nation’s small businesses, exacerbating the problems caused by a stagnant economy.
articles.lead_paragraph: Louis Licata has shelved plans to hire three more employees for his Cleveland law firm. Jeannie Macone, of Florida, is cutting back on inventory for her trinket and home décor business. In Ohio, Patrick Allen has slashed employee travel and begun paying cash for work dinners with clients of the marketing firm that he started from scratch.

articles.headline: Iran’s Top Leader Dashes Hopes for a Compromise
articles.snippet: Iran’s supreme leader, Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, raised the prospect of violence if the vast, defiant protests of opposition supporters continued.
articles.abstract: Iran’s supreme leader, Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, raised the prospect of violence if the vast, defiant protests of opposition supporters continued.
articles.lead_paragraph: TEHRAN  Iran’s supreme leader, Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, sternly cut off any compromise over the nation’s disputed elections on Friday. In a long and hard-line sermon, he declared the elections valid and warned of violence if demonstrators continue, as they have pledged, to flood the streets in defiance of the government.

articles.headline: Texas Financier and Antiguan Official Charged With Fraud
articles.snippet: Prosecutors claim that the regulator looked the other way, allowing R. Allen Stanford to run a Ponzi scheme that cheated investors out of $7 billion.
articles.abstract: Prosecutors claim that the regulator looked the other way, allowing R. Allen Stanford to run a Ponzi scheme that cheated investors out of $7 billion.
articles.lead_paragraph: HOUSTON  In June 2005, the Securities and Exchange Commission made a secret plea to Antigua’s top banking regulator, Leroy King: help investigate whether Stanford International Bank, based in the Caribbean money haven, was engaged in a huge fraud of its investors.
